data.value: The need to comply with the Physician Payment Sunshine provisions and similar laws may incur significant costs and potential penalties.
The presence of competing products may reduce sales and impact financial performance.
The ability of generic manufacturers to challenge patents and produce competing products may significantly affect market position.
The ongoing and potential challenges against patents covering JAKAFI introduce a significant risk to its market exclusivity.

elements.title: Valuation of acquisition-related contingent consideration liability

data.value: The Company’s acquisition-related contingent consideration liability consists of certain future royalty obligations on future net revenues of ICLUSIG.
The liability is remeasured to its estimated fair value each reporting period, with changes in fair value recorded in the consolidated statements of operations.
As of December 31, 2022, the acquisition-related contingent consideration liability was $221.0 million.
Auditing the valuation was complex and highly judgmental due to significant estimation required in determining fair value.
The fair value estimate was sensitive to significant assumptions such as the discount rate and projected future net revenues of ICLUSIG.
These assumptions are affected by future industry, market and economic conditions, which are inherently uncertain.

To test the estimated fair value of the acquisition-related contingent consideration liability, we performed audit procedures that included assessing the terms of the arrangement and evaluating the methodology used.
Involved valuation specialists to assist in the evaluation of the significant assumptions and methodology.
Compared significant assumptions to current industry, market, and economic trends and to the Company’s budgets and forecasts.
Assessed the historical accuracy of management’s estimates against actual performance.

elements.title: Revenues and Accruals Regarding Commercial Insurance

data.value: Commercial insurance rebates are based on data received from customers.
Rebates are invoiced and paid in arrears.
If actual future rebates vary from estimates, prior period accruals need adjustments affecting revenue.
Chargebacks are discounts for contracted customers that primarily consist of certain organizations and entities.
Manufacturers must fund 70% of the Medicare Part D coverage gap for prescription drugs.
Patients with commercial insurance may receive co-payment assistance.
Royalty revenues are based on commercial sales of licensed products.
Revenues from milestone payments under collaborative research agreements are estimated at the contract outset.

elements.title: FDA Approval and Data for JAKAFI in Polycythemia Vera and Acute Graft-Versus-Host Disease

data.value: JAKAFI
Treatment of patients with polycythemia vera (PV), steroid-refractory acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
Approved for PV by FDA in December 2014; approved for steroid-refractory acute GVHD in May 2019; approved for chronic GVHD in September 2021
RESPONSE trial, RESPONSE-2 study, REACH1 study, REACH3 study
Superior hematocrit control, overall response rate for GVHD of 57%, chronic GVHD overall response rate of 70% for JAKAFI
Thrombocytopenia, anemia, infections, edema, neutropenia

elements.title: OPZELURA Launches for Atopic Dermatitis and Vitiligo

data.value: OPZELURA (ruxolitinib) cream

data.key: FDA Approval Date for Atopic Dermatitis
data.value: September 2021
July 2022
Topical treatment for mild to moderate atopic dermatitis and nonsegmental vitiligo
Significantly more patients achieved IGA Treatment Success at Week 8 (53.8% in TRuE-AD1, 51.3% in TRuE-AD2) compared to vehicle (15.1%, 7.6%)
First and only FDA approved treatment for repigmentation of vitiligo lesions; 29.9% of patients achieving >75% improvement in F-VASI75 at Week 24

data.key: Common Adverse Reactions for Atopic Dermatitis
data.value: Nasopharyngitis, diarrhea, bronchitis, ear infection, eosinophil count increased, urticaria, folliculitis, tonsillitis, rhinorrhea
Application site acne, application site pruritus, nasopharyngitis, headache, urinary tract infection, application site erythema, pyrexia

elements.title: Clinical Trials and FDA Approval Process

data.value: Clinical trials involve administration of investigational drugs to human subjects under qualified supervision and in accordance with Good Clinical Practice.
Phases I, II, and III, each with specific objectives and populations.
Evaluate safety, dosage tolerance, metabolism, distribution, and excretion.
Evaluate dosage tolerance, identify adverse effects, and preliminary efficacy evidence.
Further evaluate efficacy and safety in expanded patient populations.
Protocols must be submitted to the FDA as part of the IND.
FDA may suspend clinical trials if significant risks are found.
Provides agreement on trial design that can form basis for effectiveness claim.
May require further studies to monitor side effects and expand indications.
Variability in time and costs for clinical trials can complicate predictions.
Including slow patient enrollment and potential delays in approvals.

This report contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties relating to future periods, future events or our future operating or financial plans or performance. In April 2021, the FDA extended the review period for the sNDA for baricitinib for moderate to severe AD by three months.
In July 2021, the FDA will not meet the PDUFA action date for baricitinib for adult moderate to severe AD.
Lilly announced that alignment with the FDA on the indicated population had not yet been reached.
In October 2020, the European Commission approved baricitinib as OLUMIANT for moderate-to-severe AD.
In December 2020, baricitinib was approved by the MHLW for moderate-to-severe AD.
In March 2020, baricitinib received Breakthrough Therapy designation for alopecia areata.
In November 2020, the FDA issued an EUA for baricitinib for COVID-19 treatment.
In July 2021, the EUA for baricitinib was broadened for treatment with or without remdesivir.
In June 2022, the FDA approved baricitinib as OLUMIANT for the treatment of COVID-19.

The FDA seeks to review NDAs and BLAs that are granted priority status more quickly than those given standard review status.

If we or our collaborators are unable to obtain regulatory approval for our drug candidates in the United States and foreign jurisdictions, we or our collaborators will not be permitted to commercialize products resulting from our research.

To obtain regulatory approval, we or our collaborators must first show that our or our collaborators' drug candidates are safe and effective for target indications through preclinical testing and clinical trials.
Completion of clinical trials may take several years and failure may occur at any stage of testing.
In June 2018, after a resubmission of the NDA, the FDA approved the 2mg dose of OLUMIANT for the treatment of adults with moderately-to-severely active rheumatoid arthritis.

This table provides patent expiration information for various drug candidates across three major markets (US, EU, and Japan). The patents extend from 2026 to 2036, with retifanlimab having the latest expiration date (2036) across all regions. Most drugs have either granted or pending patent status, with some variations between regions. Notable is ponatinib, which only shows patent information for the EU market expiring in 2026.
